page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY OF GARTMORE
page.content: The name Gartmore means "the big enclosure". At one time cattle were driven to markets in the south along the drove roads, being rested over- night in Gartmore. Place names still reflect this - Market Place, Wester & Easter Cow Park, Slaughterhouse Lane (now Park Avenue).{Gartmore House}was owned for many years by the Grahams, the first was the son of the 4th. Earl of Menteith. In 1730 Robert Graham MP was Lord Rector of Glasgow University, and Sir Walter Scott wrote parts of "Rob Roy" there. Many of Rob Roy's exploits took place around Gartmore. Gartmore was a true{estate village built on a rocky hill as the surround- ing land was so fertile. 90 years ago there was a bakery, butcher's, 2 pubs, 3 cobblers, smiddy, 2 churches, and a secondary school. Until 1949 the rail- way went from Aberfoyle to Buchlyvie.
